channel.title: Google launches Google Drive
channel.description:
https://drive.google.com/start#home [i]http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2012/04/introducing-google-drive-yes-really.html [/i]
Today, we’re introducing Google Drive—a place where you can create, share, collaborate, and keep all of your stuff. Whether you’re working with a friend on a joint research project, planning a wedding with your fiancé or tracking a budget with roommates, you can do it in Drive. You can upload and access all of your files, including videos, photos, Google Docs, PDFs and beyond.
Looks like it's meant to compete with services like Dropbox and Microsoft's various cloud storage services Personally, I'm quite excited for it, I like having my services through Google, they seem to do things better than others do 5Gb of free space compared to Dropbox's 2Gb [img]http://puu.sh/rLs2.png[/img] Also, you can now share common filetypes that might require a program to open, such as .psd, .ai, online in the web browser without having to have Photoshop, Illustrator, etc, installed. I'm not sure if this feature was available prior to the launch but it actually seems like it could be incredibly useful for sharing project ideas with co-workers or customers that don't have specialized software installed :)
View anything. Open over 30 file types right in your browser—including HD video, Adobe Illustrator and Photoshop—even if you don’t have the program installed on your computer.

item.title: Google launches Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

[quote=“Pwnd, post:15, topic:440761”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=543434.msg3984229#msg3984229 date=1335675448]
I don’t see anything about security or their policy on what they can/can’t do with your files, so I won’t be using it.

If you are in the market for something like this, I fully recommend instead a company called SpiderOak:
https://spideroak.com/

They actually encrypt the data on your computer before sending it to their servers, so not even they have access to it. This combined with versioning, data de-duplication, and truly cross-platform apps, makes it the best sync’ing solution out there as far as I know.
[/quote]I’m sure if they have the means of encrypting it, they can also decrypt it…[/quote]

Everything is encrypted on the client side (your computer) before even being sent over the internet, so they never have clear-text data and can’t do anything with it.

Read full topic

item.title: Google launches Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @R.I.P_RSC R.I.P RSC
item.description:
@R.I.P_RSC wrote:

tL:

That is the value in these services, the synchronisation, not really the storage.

Exactly. I use it alot for my school work. I do part of my work in groups, so the ability to share certain parts of your documents is quite handy too. And being able to look at previous versions of the same document is great too.

Read full topic

item.title: Google launches Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @classic mopmans little slave
item.description:
@classic wrote:

awesome

Read full topic

item.title: Google launches Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @tL tL
item.description:
@tL wrote:

Also a large physical disk isn’t available across all your devices. That is what I use these services for, I can be editing a document on desktop, save it, it’ll be uploaded and synchronised to my other devices and I can then view or edit it from my laptop, phone or tablet.

That is the value in these services, the synchronisation, not really the storage.

Read full topic

item.title: Google launches Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @z z
item.description:
@z wrote:

[quote=“eczema3, post:3, topic:440761”]1TB for $50 a month? That’s like half the cost of buying a physical drive… WTF

Still, it’s brilliant free[/quote]$50 a month vs $100 lifetime fee (tho having a hdd irl is riskier…)

Also, don’t you need to have an iPhone to even register an account with iCloud…

Read full topic

runescape3dude:

I thought it meant like an online driving thing using street view… Online storage is just lame…

Cloud storage is incredibly useful for work/school, having a single folder across all of your devices with your documents, pdfs, images, etc, all up to date from where you left off last is so useful in both personal/professional life

item.title: Google launches Google Drive
item.dc:creator: @bloodrayne bloodrayne
item.description:
@bloodrayne wrote:

google.com

Google Drive - Cloud Storage & File Backup for Photos, Docs & More

Get access to files anywhere through secure cloud storage and file backup for your photos, videos, files and more with Google Drive.

http://googleblog.blogspot.com/2012/04/introducing-google-drive-yes-really.html

Today, we’re introducing Google Drive—a place where you can create, share, collaborate, and keep all of your stuff. Whether you’re working with a friend on a joint research project, planning a wedding with your fiancé or tracking a budget with roommates, you can do it in Drive. You can upload and access all of your files, including videos, photos, Google Docs, PDFs and beyond.

Looks like it’s meant to compete with services like Dropbox and Microsoft’s various cloud storage services

Personally, I’m quite excited for it, I like having my services through Google, they seem to do things better than others do

5Gb of free space compared to Dropbox’s 2Gb

Also, you can now share common filetypes that might require a program to open, such as .psd, .ai, online in the web browser without having to have Photoshop, Illustrator, etc, installed. I’m not sure if this feature was available prior to the launch but it actually seems like it could be incredibly useful for sharing project ideas with co-workers or customers that don’t have specialized software installed

View anything. Open over 30 file types right in your browser—including HD video, Adobe Illustrator and Photoshop—even if you don’t have the program installed on your computer.

Read full topic
